natural problem: What is the tens digit in the sum $7! + 8! + 9! + \cdots + 2006!$?
natural solution: Since $n!$ contains the product $2\cdot5\cdot10= 100$ whenever $n\ge 10$,  it suffices to determine the tens digit of \[ 7! + 8! + 9! = 7! (1 + 8 + 8\cdot9) = 5040(1 + 8 + 72)= 5040\cdot81. \]This  is the same as the units digit of $4\cdot 1$, which is $\boxed{4}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and fact :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. fact n = prod (\<lambda>i. i) {1..n}"
and h1 : "n = 2006"
shows  "digit (sum fact {7..n}) 10 = 4"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the tens digit in the sum $7! + 8! + 9! + \cdots + 2006!$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Since $n!$ contains the product $2\cdot5\cdot10= 100$ whenever $n\ge 10$,  it suffices to determine the tens digit of \[ 7! + 8! + 9! = 7! (1 + 8 + 8\cdot9) = 5040(1 + 8 + 72)= 5040\cdot81. \]This  is the same as the units digit of $4\cdot 1$, which is $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and fact :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. fact n = prod (\<lambda>i. i) {1..n}"
and h1 : "n = 2006"
shows  "digit (sum fact {7..n}) 10 = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the last digit (in base 10) of the sum of the factorials of all the numbers from 7 to 2006. The final answer is 4.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and sum_factorials :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum_factorials 7 = fact 7"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. 8 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> sum_factorials n = sum_factorials (n - 1) + fact n"
shows  "digit (sum_factorials 2006) 1 = 4"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the tens digit in the sum $7! + 8! + 9! + \cdots + 2006!$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Since $n!$ contains the product $2\cdot5\cdot10= 100$ whenever $n\ge 10$,  it suffices to determine the tens digit of \[ 7! + 8! + 9! = 7! (1 + 8 + 8\cdot9) = 5040(1 + 8 + 72)= 5040\cdot81. \]This  is the same as the units digit of $4\cdot 1$, which is $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and sum_factorials :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum_factorials 7 = fact 7"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. 8 \<le> n \<and> n \<le> 2006 \<longrightarrow> sum_factorials n = sum_factorials (n - 1) + fact n"
shows  "digit (sum_factorials 2006) 1 = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Consider a sequence of factorials where the sum of the first 7 factorials is equal to the factorial of 7. For each term from the 8th to the 2006th, the sum of factorials is equal to the previous sum plus the current factorial. Find the last digit (ones place) of the sum of the first 2006 factorials. The final answer is 4.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum_facts :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum_facts n = (\<Sum>i\<in>{7..n}. fact i)"
and h1 : "n = 2006"
shows  "digit (sum_facts n) 10 = 4"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the tens digit in the sum $7! + 8! + 9! + \cdots + 2006!$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Since $n!$ contains the product $2\cdot5\cdot10= 100$ whenever $n\ge 10$,  it suffices to determine the tens digit of \[ 7! + 8! + 9! = 7! (1 + 8 + 8\cdot9) = 5040(1 + 8 + 72)= 5040\cdot81. \]This  is the same as the units digit of $4\cdot 1$, which is $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes sum_facts :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum_facts n = (\<Sum>i\<in>{7..n}. fact i)"
and h1 : "n = 2006"
shows  "digit (sum_facts n) 10 = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the last digit of the sum of the factorials of all integers from 7 to 2006. The final answer is 4.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum_fact :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum_fact = (\<lambda> n. sum (\<lambda> i. fact i) {7..n})"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 7"
shows  "tens_digit (sum_fact 2006) = 4"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the tens digit in the sum $7! + 8! + 9! + \cdots + 2006!$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Since $n!$ contains the product $2\cdot5\cdot10= 100$ whenever $n\ge 10$,  it suffices to determine the tens digit of \[ 7! + 8! + 9! = 7! (1 + 8 + 8\cdot9) = 5040(1 + 8 + 72)= 5040\cdot81. \]This  is the same as the units digit of $4\cdot 1$, which is $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes sum_fact :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "sum_fact = (\<lambda> n. sum (\<lambda> i. fact i) {7..n})"
and h1 : "n \<ge> 7"
shows  "tens_digit (sum_fact 2006) = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the tens digit of the sum of the factorials from 7 to 2006, where the sum of factorials is defined as $\sum_{i=7}^{n} i!$. The final answer is 4.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes factorial_sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "factorial_sum n = (\<Sum>i=7..n. fact i)"
and h1 : "n = 2006"
shows  "digit (factorial_sum n) 1 = 4"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the tens digit in the sum $7! + 8! + 9! + \cdots + 2006!$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Since $n!$ contains the product $2\cdot5\cdot10= 100$ whenever $n\ge 10$,  it suffices to determine the tens digit of \[ 7! + 8! + 9! = 7! (1 + 8 + 8\cdot9) = 5040(1 + 8 + 72)= 5040\cdot81. \]This  is the same as the units digit of $4\cdot 1$, which is $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes factorial_sum :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "factorial_sum n = (\<Sum>i=7..n. fact i)"
and h1 : "n = 2006"
shows  "digit (factorial_sum n) 1 = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Find the last digit of the sum of the factorials of all integers from 7 to 2006. The final answer is 4.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes factorial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "factorial 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n > 0. factorial n = n * factorial (n - 1)"
and h2 : "sum (\<lambda>n. factorial n) {7..2006} = x"
shows  "tens_digit x = 4"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the tens digit in the sum $7! + 8! + 9! + \cdots + 2006!$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Since $n!$ contains the product $2\cdot5\cdot10= 100$ whenever $n\ge 10$,  it suffices to determine the tens digit of \[ 7! + 8! + 9! = 7! (1 + 8 + 8\cdot9) = 5040(1 + 8 + 72)= 5040\cdot81. \]This  is the same as the units digit of $4\cdot 1$, which is $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes factorial :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "factorial 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n > 0. factorial n = n * factorial (n - 1)"
and h2 : "sum (\<lambda>n. factorial n) {7..2006} = x"
shows  "tens_digit x = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given the factorial function defined as $factorial(0) = 1$ and $factorial(n) = n * factorial(n-1)$ for all $n > 0$, find the tens digit of the sum of factorials of the numbers in the range from 7 to 2006. The final answer is 4.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and sum_fact :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 7 \<longrightarrow> sum_fact n = (\<Sum>k = 7..n. fact k)"
and h1 : "n = 2006"
shows  "tens_digit (sum_fact n) = 4"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the tens digit in the sum $7! + 8! + 9! + \cdots + 2006!$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Since $n!$ contains the product $2\cdot5\cdot10= 100$ whenever $n\ge 10$,  it suffices to determine the tens digit of \[ 7! + 8! + 9! = 7! (1 + 8 + 8\cdot9) = 5040(1 + 8 + 72)= 5040\cdot81. \]This  is the same as the units digit of $4\cdot 1$, which is $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and sum_fact :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. n \<ge> 7 \<longrightarrow> sum_fact n = (\<Sum>k = 7..n. fact k)"
and h1 : "n = 2006"
shows  "tens_digit (sum_fact n) = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Find the tens digit of the sum of the factorials of the numbers from 7 to 2006. The final answer is 4.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = fact n"
and h1 : "f 7 + f 8 + f 9 + ... + f 2006 = a"
shows  "tens_digit a = 4"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the tens digit in the sum $7! + 8! + 9! + \cdots + 2006!$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Since $n!$ contains the product $2\cdot5\cdot10= 100$ whenever $n\ge 10$,  it suffices to determine the tens digit of \[ 7! + 8! + 9! = 7! (1 + 8 + 8\cdot9) = 5040(1 + 8 + 72)= 5040\cdot81. \]This  is the same as the units digit of $4\cdot 1$, which is $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = fact n"
and h1 : "f 7 + f 8 + f 9 + ... + f 2006 = a"
shows  "tens_digit a = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the tens digit of the sum of the factorials of the numbers from 7 to 2006, that is, $7! + 8! + 9! + ... + 2006!$. The final answer is 4.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f n = fact n"
and h1 : "sum f {7..2006} mod 100 = k"
shows  "k div 10 = 4"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the tens digit in the sum $7! + 8! + 9! + \cdots + 2006!$? The final Answer is 4
 ### Proof
 Since $n!$ contains the product $2\cdot5\cdot10= 100$ whenever $n\ge 10$,  it suffices to determine the tens digit of \[ 7! + 8! + 9! = 7! (1 + 8 + 8\cdot9) = 5040(1 + 8 + 72)= 5040\cdot81. \]This  is the same as the units digit of $4\cdot 1$, which is $\boxed{4}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "f n = fact n"
and h1 : "sum f {7..2006} mod 100 = k"
shows  "k div 10 = 4"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Consider a function $f(n)$ that computes the factorial of a natural number $n$. Calculate the sum of the factorials of all numbers in the range from $7$ to $2006$, inclusive. Find the last two digits of the sum (the remainder when the sum is divided by $100$), and then divide that number by $10$. What is the result? The final answer is $4$.
